flower/blossom/CL:朵[duo3],支[zhi1],束[shu4],把[ba3],盆[pen2],簇[cu4]/fancy pattern/florid/to spend (money, time)/(coll.) lecherous/lustful

to think through/to invest effort in thinking about/to consider thoroughly

sentences.english: Lead the relationship between back and double grace, specially effort to coax back double grace.
sentences.chinese: 辛勇爲了挽回與雙怡的關係，特地花心思哄回雙怡。

sentences.english: It is the beautiful heart because of Zheng Yu really, li Lin just leaves Zheng Yu?
sentences.chinese: 真的是因爲鄭宇的花心，李琳才離開鄭宇的嗎？

sentences.english: If you're well dressed, she says you are a playboy.
Gold wall fabric inlays are on each side of the mantle over mahogany bookshelves.
sentences.chinese: 金牆壁織品鑲嵌細工在披風的每邊在桃花心木書架的。

sentences.english: A maiden with a pure heart coming across playboys is commonly seen in TV series.
sentences.chinese: 純情少女遇上花心漢是電視劇中常用的情節。

sentences.english: We'll hike through mahogany forests and pay a visit to some Taiwanese macaques.
sentences.chinese: 一塊到臺南的桃花心木林爬山，和到烏山看獼猴。

sentences.english: My heart is because I have been looking for me.
sentences.chinese: 我花心，是因爲我一直在尋找適合我的人。

sentences.english: It does not mean he actually prefers hamburger.
sentences.chinese: 花心並不意味着他真的就喜歡漢堡包。

sentences.english: For example, architecture of mahogany, it likes humid, worrying about drying.
sentences.chinese: 例如，桃花心木建築，它喜歡潮溼，對乾燥擔心。

sentences.english: Tender and beautiful, such as by, fickleness is empty.
All the materials he uses are brass, mahogany and galvanized iron.
sentences.chinese: 所有材料的用途，他是黃銅，桃花心木和鍍鋅鐵。
從本性上講，男人是花心的。

sentences.english: I'm going to use mahogany to make the book-case.
sentences.chinese: 我打算用桃花心木做書櫥。

sentences.english: D. Edison Chen is a goddamned rich philanderer.
sentences.chinese: 陳冠希是一個有錢的花心大蘿蔔。

(coll.) womanizer/skirt-chaser
single-minded/concentrated
lit. to pick the flowers and trample the grass (idiom)/fig. to womanize/to frequent brothels/to sow one's wild oats
change of affection, shift of love (idiom); to change one's feelings to another love/to fall in love with sb else
fickle (woman)
to fondle the flowers and trample the grass (idiom)/to womanize/to frequent brothels/to sow one's wild oats
to cease to be faithful
lit. to stand with each foot in a different boat (idiom)/fig. to have it both ways/to run after two hares/(especially) to have two lovers at the same time
to have a foot in both camps/to have a bet each way/to be having an affair
to change at once on seeing sth different (idiom); loving fads and novelty/never satisfied with what one has
affectionate/an affectionate person
affectionate/passionate/emotional/sentimental
to do the splits (gymnastics)/(Tw) two-timing (in romantic relationships)/Taiwan pr. [pi1 tui3]
(of a flower) to attract bees and butterflies/(fig.) to attract the opposite sex/to flirt
lit. say three in the morning but four in the evening (idiom); to change sth that is already settled upon/indecisive/to blow hot and cold
